review: Big enough to get lost or hide out in.
served my time in Wally World
Change is the only constant thing at Walmart
date_position: Nov 7, 2021 - Electronics and Entertainment Team Lead
pros: Nice people for work with
Advancement opportunities, great at developing skills, great place to learn a skill and grow your resume, or grow with the company.

Size and scope of the enterprise means that whatever your niche is, there is likely a team or product that wants your specialization. Living near the corporate headquarters is definitely a selling point. Northwest Arkansas was amazing when I first started and has only kept getting better.

Your typical soulless grind to earn Walmart another dollar of off my back. We're expendable, as I was told by a female Troll of a supervisor. Fantastic way to demonstrate how we are not valued as human beings or even respected out of decency.

 The job paid decently for the infamously cheap employer area and the hours were plentiful, albeit only because i had open availability. The insurance and benefits were terrible from what i heard, so i did not bother to sign up for any when my 6 months came up. The supervisors were nice and respectable, so that was a plus. Most of the coworkers were fine people, with the exception of one dwarf.

Suffice to say i did not do well in my role and was fired eventually, but i did not despair but rejoice as I was once more free and i laid my head down with a satisfied smile.

Endless opportunities for growth and promotions or movements into new areas of the business that you will gain experience and further leverage to know the business and be successful. Bonus payout tied to performance.
There’s job security in the sense that retail is an industry that won’t be going anywhere for the foreseeable future. If you’re young the pay is okay.
Not working hard gets you rewarded. Training is only used in testing not actual daily performance. If you go to jail because of something you did at this job you are welcomed back.

I’ll be forever grateful they hire people over 60. I couldn’t get a response from other local companies despite an excellent recent employment record. 

 The hourly crew on my shift was great, funny and supportive, as long as you weren’t a slacker.

Every week we got free bakery goods in the break room.

*Reasonable Current Management
*Friendly but Professional Management
*Pleasant coworkers for the moment.
Can trust Dave and Tom, their performance is so exceptional that we all gain bonuses and benefits, and they advocate for our needs heavily.
I enjoy using the mass email blast to remind my clients about promotions, discounts, etc. i think it's definitely worth the monthly spend! it keeps my day-to-day business steady and organized.
cons: Not many monies left for wife

Understaffing issues negatively affects all parts of their business. However, Walmart has increased their minimum hourly rate with hopes to attract more committed employees, and retain better employees.

It's a retailer not an IT company. It's got that baked into its bones and it shows sometimes with the decision/procurement process. Tech debt is pretty high in some areas and often it won't be addressed due to penny wise, pound foolish thinking. Northwest Arkansas and by proxy the Bentonville campus is liberal for the South but conservative for the tech industry standards. Sometimes people are waaaaayyyyy out of step with that reality and either want the Good Old Boy days to come back or can't understand why their deeply held views are labelled as being Social Justice Warrior-esque.
Start of shift and the dawn of the next day.

Different orgs have different priorities and moving from one to another (such as operations to HR/Global people) you will find that topics in the office your former team would consider marginal and petty are actively embraced to enable associates who are insubordinate and require you earn their respect when you come in at a leadership level…in operations the associates are taught to act with urgency and move forward and take the guidance of leadership, regardless of how new they are to your team or not.

Pay is static through positions middle management like team leads. It’s not based on skill or how well you do, everyone gets paid pretty much the same unless you work on food side. Company does not pay holiday pay, you have to use your own PTO if you’d like to be paid the two days of the year the stores are closed ( thanksgiving and Christmas). The scheduling across all positions is much less than flexible than in the past. Team leads pretty much run the store, and if you close the store, it very well ends up as you running half of the store for $19/HR, which is just chump change for doing a job that used to pay 50-60k in salary. Overall not worth it.

All ways do what they tell you or get voted off the island so to speak. It's takes one of your  piers 1 manager, 1 upper management to comment write you up. to get rid of you if they find a reason. Or simply clock in and out wrong on time clock, seconds count too. This sets you up to get fired quickly.For example if a associate stabbed some one with a knife and  goes to jail you'll get rehired back. Clock in and out wrong they won't ever hire you back again. This was a actual Instance that occurred while working there. You may be asked to do 5 different jobs none which you were hired for. No manager will back you up or fix anything you have a problem with. I went in a happy angel walked out soulless demon who hates people. But this is what Wal-Mart does to you and type of people who shop there contribute. Only leaving will you become a happy person again. Give Wal-Mart-5 stars for so many different reasons.

Other than that, it could be a nightmare. The work was extremely physical. I expected that but not the unsafe conditions. Example: When unloading delivery trucks, we were often doing unsupported heavy lifting above our heads. And there were always trip hazards around our feet. 

The HVAC system in the back died and it took them 2 weeks (Fla in summer) before they brought us fans. I had to change into dry clothes on my lunch break. BTW, employees use the public restrooms. There aren’t any behind the scenes. 

Training was too generic, nothing specific to the job. I wasn’t even given a box cutter the first day I was stocking on the floor! I saw that happen to many other newbies. We were supposed to make marks on boxes we didn’t finish but weren’t provided markers. 

Pay was better than fast food, $11, but unfair considering all the job entailed.

Extremely rude, unreasonable, and hostile customers, making you have to be skeptical of their intentions even with something as benign as getting a car for them when you're not supposed to leave your post due to position.
Coworkers rarely know what their job entails, so whoever steps in to cover Self Checkout rarely knows that they need to watch the customer, not check them out at the front desk,which let's people easily steal.
Corporate is extremely disconnected from what it's like and what's needed to actually keep the store running and back backwards policies and requirementsthat run quality to the ground, or don't consider lack of staffing or minimal staffing situations.
When an appointment is upcharged during service , the amount due is reverted back to the original booking causing the business to lose money.

review: Not the most motivated place to work
Job is not worth the headache
a racist company to work for!
Can get overwhelming at times but decent pay
Good job to start in automotive but not the best
pros:
Able to meet some interesting characters.
Free Schooling benefits for pt and ft employees through the Live Better U! education program.
Flexible with scheduling my days off.

Decent money
Excellent benefits
Growth opportunities
Flexible schedule

Good benefits
Co-workers become family
Good resources on the company portal
Continuing education resources
There's a great push on Diversity and Inclusion in the Metro areas

When i first started, i liked working for walmart. they are a great place to work with good pay for a starting job or some people make a career out of it. they also will assist in paying to help further your education which i think is great.

- the money is some of the best in this city for a job with no experience required
- it is simple to learn
- work never really changes, always the same. Sometimes there is more to stock, sometimes less
overall, has some great benefits!
Easy Money. Relaxed atmosphere. Good Exercise. Hour Lunch and 2, 15min, breaks. Nice Managers. Helpful Co-Workers. No Customers for most of the night so unbothered work.

$14 an hour starting pay.
Depending on what role they have you some are easier than others. 
- Dispensing: Bring the order out to the customer.
- Staging: You help organize the location of customers' orders for the dispensers.
- Picking: You go out throughout the store and pick the customer's orders. 

Our store is not always running at full capacity and we have to shut down because we simply do not have enough people. 

There really aren't that many pros other than $14 an hr.

Good pay for managers, good 401(k) match, a good bonus if you work in a good profitable store. A good company to invest money in but I wouldn’t recommend working there if you’re looking for a long-term job life time job. I only had 2 good store managers in my 20 year career.

Basically the reason why you'd have this job is because you're either down low, or want the benefits. Free education (not actually any good universities except for arizona state, but not that many good programs. Somewhat okay healthcare, if you're military this job is great if you're going to college due to military differential pay.
cons:
Leadership can be difficult to work for at times.
Easy to get "lost in the crowd" with so many employees.
Quite a bit of rules and regulations that are fireable offenses.

Mixed leadership
General public 
Negative company perception

Aggressive company to rank among the retail work
Associates pay isn't the best 
Upper management has a lack of compassion towards associates and/or lower management
No work/life balance once you have reached salary position
Not a lot of talent that gets promoted
Always playing catch up and never able to teach and train

some of the downsides i found over my almost 6 years is the community. each store is way different than the rest which can be good but how some stores do things and manage situations is different from other stores. at the time that im writing this, there is a lot of logistical problems going on. so a problem is that customers would come in expecting items to be there and they arent. this has become a nightmare for associates. 

Another big con i have found is the management training. salaried management goes through the same training and is pretty universal. the lack of training i have found is in the team leads. to me it seemed like there was little leadership training and more task delegation training to fit that boss or manager role and not the "team leader" role.

- management does not work well with associates and themselves (There is no communication and suggestions by associates to management for improving processes will be ignored)
- High expectations for stocking times despite not having enough staff/ not scheduling enough staff
- Management consistently lies and corporate policy is either disregarded or not followed
- they discourage you from using the time off you have EARNED and threaten reprimanding you if you leave early by using this time in the guise of "productivity".
management and departments forced to good employees!
On feet all night, lifting, bending, squatting, and climbing. Some naggy coworkers

Generally the whole business strucutre in terms of managemnt/leadership.
Sometimes impolite customers but Online Pickup and Delivery (OPD) customers are generally better than the sales floor customers.

Dispensing can and will get tiring, sometimes it feels like people be ordering the whole store. 9/10 times a customer's item in an order will be substituted. Our job is 100% reliant on technology, if there are system shut downs it's gonna be a long day.

Team leads are constantly nagging you to stay busy. Sometimes making you do busywork. 

getting pulled to do stocking or do front-end returns.

Working at Walmart in general has a high turnover. I don't recommend working for Walmart for a long time. No one ever stays long enough to get good at what they do.

District manages and up can be pleasant but some are real unpleasant. It’s the lucky if you work for a decent manager and they either help creat a good working atmosphere or make a hostile negative working environment.
Company has very high turnover. Most stores turn over were 80-120 percent. If you didn’t go over that goal then you were doing good. I think this speaks for itself.

Customers absolutely suck. I'm not a patient person and dealing with customers who read one thing on the internet are insufferable and have no idea how businesses work and try to undermine my expertise (i'm also a blackhawk mechanic in the military) if you are really good at your job you will be able to get promotions fast, but that comes with practically living at the store especially if you are understaffed like every other ACC

review: Decent job if you have good supervisors
Has its good days and bad
Take the good with the bad
Each location has it's own attributes, I happen to be in a great location!
pros: Walmart pays better than a lot of retail jobs and the store I work at is clean. My supervisors are kind to me and that makes a big difference.
Plant care and outdoor work. You are kept busy and get to work multiple tasks. I had a lot of fun working here and the work was fulfilling.
I loved working at Walmart it was awesome great working environment amazing people to work with until it came to the management
Good teamwork, easy work, good place to make friends if you’re social, you can also keep to yourself shopping all day if you aren’t that social, good diversity
You can really find community within your department, sometimes also with management as an associate. There really is someone for everyone to get along to. Pretty good for long term work.

You can work as many hours as you want, shifts go by quickly because you can stay busy, lots of variety in duties and helping customers is always interesting. Great opportunity to become close with co-workers.
Full time employee-401k, health/dental benefits, PTO, Stocks (matched 6% for every $1

I loved working with people as management. This position is very high-paced (I’d typically walk roughly 9 miles a day) and also very rewarding to develop associates to achieve a non-stop increase of companies expectations. The company offers a lot of opportunities, provided the motivation to grow is proven by dedication.
Associates are one big family, who were always willing to assist when needed.
Good pay, Education help, and more
cons: Making the apparel section not a mess every day gets tiring and frustrating. Many customers have no respect for the store and the merchandise, leaving things all over the floor. Depending on who the supervisors are, you may get a lot of or no appreciation. Some of them are kind and some are very unkind.

It is seasonal and you will have to work in other places in the store during fall and winter. But this also has its benefits. Heavy lifting (although I enjoyed the manual labor of the job, most do not). $.
Management sucked all they cared about was them and if they were able to be at home with there family didn’t give a crap about you and yours

Gave us a raise but took away our bonuses so it barely made a difference, things constantly changing when it’s not for the better, dispensing in the rain/heat with no cover and not enough help is agonizing, penalties for our department if the shelves aren’t stocked correctly, customers can easily scam us and get away with it. It’s just very easy but if it was any harder of a job i would quit.

The pay for some departments is really unbalanced. Some people work the hardest and get paid the least, and thats often a problem. You really really have to be involved in your own progress, you wont receive feedback unless you hunt down your manager, and even then they almost never have anything productive for you to work on. As such it's harder to get promoted if you dont know what you're doing wrong. The hours are inconsistent most of the time, especially for upper management. High expectations but zero accountability for the lack of help you receive

All of the above are dependent on local management... majority of those who quit from my store say it is management. They will probably schedule you maximum hours and may try to schedule outside of availability. Punishment by "points" for calling in, 6 points within certain time frame means you get fired. No holiday pay, double points for calling in on these days. Time-off requests may be denied, even using PTO.
Nothing I've seen so far has been negative.

It only takes one senior level management to tarnish an other-wise respectable image. Vice Presidents, Regional Managers and other senior leadership are far too busy to actually be leaders and allow they’re subordinates to operate as they please. Claiming plausible deniability actually still works out for them. The term leadership is disgustingly misinterpreted, the “open door” policy is a joke and just like the rest of all giant corporations, they genuinely do not care about the little people whom they rely on and with no thought of morality will throw you away in a heartbeat. It doesn’t matter how much extra you did for them or how much time you spent away from your aging children to be a “team player”. At the end of the day, we’re all replaceable and loyalty, compassion and fair treatment are merely power words used to make us feel like a member of a family.

Network infrastructure both within the store and on the network overall could use some upgrades. WIFI signal near the outer walls could use boosting, as well as network processing times when querying seemed to lack even during off-peak times.
Not really anything other than tedeus tasks but its alright

review: Not a shabby job for work experience and development
Both what I thought and not what I thought.....
pros: As long as you got some friends and a decent work schedule that doesn’t stray into different times during the day, you should be good. A pro tip would be to stretch everything in your body, especially if you’re new. It may seem like a lot to do at first, but like everything in life you gotta go through hardships to be grateful for the present. If you didn’t get that, it means everybody struggles at some point but everyday is a step forward from where you were yesterday.
Flexible hours, easy work, friendly environment
There are honestly no pros for working for this business. The cons outweighed the pros being part time imo.

Pharmacy software is user-friendly and there are many safeguards to prevent errors throughout the process of filling a prescription. There is typically more coverage and less focus on metrics than other retail pharmacies.

* Fair PTO & PPTO
* Opportunities to advance are there for exceptional workers
* Scheduling on the app was a solid move
Well I guess the pay was decent and I met some really amazing customers who really appreciate your work

Work from home, they provide you with all the equipment you need to get the job done and it’s all top notch electronics, there’s never really any issues with their stuff or their network. Even though you’re working remote you still have instant access to leadership, tech support and peers.
The people I work with and the 10% discount card

Good culture,PT0,401K,
Employee reviews are generally of very good quality, provide complementary views and give a good picture of the organization. All SaaS, easy to use, fast, immediate results.

The pay was decent for a part-time, entry-level position. Note: the online order fulfillment positions pay more than the floor associate positions. I found the culture at my store to be surprisingly chill and supportive. I found myself regretting that I had to quit, because I enjoyed the people and the environment.
cons: If anything, just make sure you have a lot of patience and knowledge to deal with customers and people in general. Also, make sure to always ask for help from others.
long hours at times, poor management
There are so many that I can't even imagine speaking on them because listing the reasons will drain the life out of you. The business sucks please just trust me lol.

Pharmacy software is slow and bulky. Walmart uses Facts & Comparisons for drug information, which is one of the worst available to pharmacists. The company's attempt at inventory automation made the situation worse.

* Some days overloaded with responsibility (to the point where you are set up to fail honestly)
* While PPTO is no problem (albeit some stern talking from HR) almost impossible to use PTO any less than a month and a half
* Petty drama and office politics that are neigh impossible to escape

Everything from the discrimination to the favoritism to the retaliation as well as slander and just plain hostile gross work environments and those who try to follow Walmart policy and health codes the way that customers hope that they would get fired for unjust false reasoning and when you report it to home office home office does not give you a second chance doesn't even look into it they take the managers word for it and that's it even if you have recordings documents pictures witnesses and police reports

They put a lot of emphasis on having built a solid foundation, anchored by four core values that they fail to uphold. Companies don’t have to have “core values” to be successful so I find it very shameful that they went out of their way to conjure up such a facade, just to run it through the mud.

The "task times" given to complete stocking shelves. Make you park nearly as far away as possible. The paperwork received at orientation states that WalMart understands that you can't be expected to be available to work 24/7, 365. But if and when you do call in or have to leave early, points are given to you against attendance. At 4.5 points, they start looking to replace you. At 5 points---you are gone.
There are times where not all companies have enough information and the reviews on some are very old and can be misleading.

The only downside I can report is the physicality of the work. Then again, I'm no spring chicken. For a young person working through school or looking for a career foothold in a stable company, I think this is a great opportunity. But if you're middle-aged with some physical issues, I would exercise caution. There's lots of repetitive, moderately heavy lifting (40-packs of bottled water seemed to be the most common offender here) which is fine if you use good lifting techniques. --Lift with your legs--keep your back straight-- But when you are trying to load heavy products into a customer's junky back seat, you may find yourself compromising your back just to get the job done. Also, there are times that are chaotically busy. The trick is not to lose your cool, no matter how frazzled you feel.

review: It's hard to recommend, but it could be worse I guess...
pros: Always something to do . No idleness
Lunch break 30 min. Great 401 k match. Most help tech wise than any other retail pharmacy

People are typically nice and polite. I've met some amazing people. I loved the culture of servant leadership from the top. 
Can get exposed to a lot of different subjects/industries.
Some areas have great teams and work cultures.
Doug, the CEO, seems really great and can help employees feel bought into the mission. 
Does some great Corporate Responsibility and Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion work.

My experience working for Walmart great. I enjoyed the work that I performed, most of my coworkers, my supervisor and the assistant manager over our department. I felt the benefits for the job that I held was appropriate and should be expected. Walmart has many programs for employees that are trying to better themselves if an employee only apply themselves.
Good hours and nobody is on top of you to get work done
Pay is good and the shift is good and management is good
Consistent schedules and good pay, if your store dose well you can get a nice bonus every qurter (every 3 months) management in my current store is very friendly
Straightforward, typical, fairly predictable, and mostly friendly co-workers
Rewarding. Seeing project from start to finish is really gratifying. Teaming with the Stores to complete a project.
Flexible hours and friendly working environment
cons: Flexibility demand is high so inflexibility when comes to scheduling.
Walmart has the most rules and regulations to follow out of any retail pharmacy. You must follow every sop procedure

LOTS of layoffs. I had my roles eliminated 3 times in 7 years. 
Employee experience varies widely. Some teams are great, some are bad. Onboarding as an external candidate is really hard, especially because it's so big. 
Getting promoted within the company can be really challenging. I had a terrible time in every role , even when I was really successful in role. 
Plays favorites. A select few are very successful and the rest of overworked and undervalued. 
They also blatantly try to keep your wages as low as possible. 
I never felt valued for my contributions or work. 
Treats their employees like cogs in a machine. 
Performance evaluations are biased, unhelpful, and frustrating. 
Culture is so operations and action focused that strategy can go out the window. Lots of people spend most of their capacity on short term, high stress, crisis problem solving. 
So fast paced and understaffed that every job is designed to be 1.5-2 jobs. Achieving anything and being recognized for your contributions is really hard.
Workaholic culture. It's better then it used to be but still high stress.
Pay and benefits fit the positions. I don't know why a person would expect more from unskilled jobs though.
Managers expect too much of new employees
U have to be in shape

In most stores there is little to no communication with management, unrealistic expectations and if you ever step up in management your position may get deleted at any time, so there is little to no job security,
Managers not on the same page, seasoned co-workers see their way as the best way
Working nights takes some getting use to.
Rude customers and dirty store

review: Good pay for a quick job
pros: Flexible hours and friendly working environment
Gave u your assignment and let you be
Choose your own hours, relatively high pay

The company description section of your business plan is typically the second section, coming after the executive summary.1﻿ The company description outlines vital details about your company, such as where you are located, how large the company is, what you do, and what you hope to accomplish.2﻿


The company description of your business plan describes the vision and direction of the company so potential lenders and partners can develop an accurate impression about who you are.3﻿


What to Include
The exact elements included in your company description can vary, but some elements are more common than others and most likely should be part of the section:

Company name: The official name of yo

Almost everyone is super welcoming and nice
Pretty good pay
Super active
Awesome team leads and coaches
Work is enjoyable, pays well
Decent pay for the ease of getting the job.
Easy with good hours yeah

Flexible hours
great benefits and insurance
Great pay, good co workers
cons: Rude customers and dirty store
The pay for night stalker
A lot of physical activity

That’s right, company stories are not just for tech start-ups. Every business, no matter how big or small, needs to tell a story on their website. It’s just another step towards building a better website for your small business.
Having a story to share on your website is a great way to attract new customers. Remember that people choose to hire professionals that 1) They like, 2) they trust, and 3) they feel like they know. The same holds true for businesses – we’re people after all.

We’ll show you how to write an effective business description using the power of storytelling. Follow our simple guide to create your own small business description in less than 20 minutes.

Upper management has no clue how much workload we have, and tries to push on more and more without hiring more help. Even if we have our backs against the wall, OT is never allowed for tech except in very rare circumstances. You will be pulled in every direction from the moment the day starts until it ends. I will say that it is better than working at CVS or Walgreens, but that's not saying much.

Management is very unorganized and rude. They don’t schedule enough employees to cover their departments in order to keep their bonuses and expect the work to be done, and they sweat you over getting it done, even though they know they didn’t schedule enough people.

The lunch room is dirty and also doesn’t accommodate the amount of people who need a place to eat their lunch.

They make employees feel like they could lose their job at a moment’s notice over petty things. I have seen good, hard working people worked to the point of exhaustion and made to feel like they didn’t do enough.

My supervisor spoke Spanish and English, but would mostly speak Spanish. She told me that if I wanted her to speak to me, I needed to learn to speak Spanish.

When I left, they asked me to stay because I’m a good worker. NOPE. I deserve a better environment than that.

I will never work for Walmart again and I don’t recommend it.

*Constantly* changing work policies and methods from one year to the next. Everything new in 2020/2021 has been a disaster so far. Always short handed, supervisors getting laid off and having their pay removed because their raises were higher than the new cap for the lower position they were forced into. New phones they give out to associates still don't even work right. Missing key programs on 'new' system from 2015. Smart system that was supposed to be 100% gone by 2015, still around because the home office wont hire good programmers to make appropriate apps for remaining old systems. Regular associates being forced to take on duties that were once supervisor only. Have been told that associates are now basically department managers. Associates now forced to cover up to 4 departments at once instead of just one. Removed many supervisor positions to consolidate payroll. Now Team leads must cover multiple departments instead of just one. Cost cutting to the extreme, company no longer cares about associates who are not interested in climbing the crooked ladder. Quarterly Bonuses were removed and replaced with an hourly raise that did not equal even 50% of the average bonus. Used to get $300 average quarterly bonus for a regular associate. replacement raise equals to less than $150 per quarter. Corporate have replaced carrot with stick. Were given PPTO to shield from tardy points, only to have it eat into regular PTO and have rates adjusted so associates get less total PPTO&PTO overall now.
Minimum 30 minute unpaid lunch must be taken.

The only downside at Walmart it is tough to climb the ladder it takes years of pursuit in a style similar to what a politician might go thru essentially being accepted by every employee as deserving to be promoted. Another words it doesn't happen easily. If you are a hard worker, get ready to be used hard and put up wet. I suggest taking everything you do at a pace because if you are out to impress you had better be prepared to keep that pace because it will become required and expected without any kind of gratification or appreciation for putting forth extra at work. There is not any type of reward system for someone who puts in 110% and doing so will not benefit you. I recommend watching people your first couple of days and paying attention to stay in the mainstream average. You will not get a raise and will not gain for extra hard work ethic and from personal experience let me say that learning this lesson is hard on your motivation once you have. So don't do it. Set a pace you can easily handle and stick to it no matter what and enjoy your job its a cinch.

They don't really care about you personally. If you have an issue and don't harass everyone, nothing will change. When I got hired, I was supposed to make 15 an hour, but something happened within the system, and I was hired at 11. I was notified about this at orientation, and that it would be fixed before my shift the next day. A couple of days passed and I noticed that my title hadn't changed, so I went to talk to someone about it, just to get an update. I was told that it was being fixed and to wait a few days. A week passed, and nothing was fixed. When I went to ask about it I was told that it was supposed to be fixed that Saturday which was about five days away. Although I was pleased to finally hear something other than ambiguity, I was very annoyed, especially because I continued to make 11 until the following Saturday; a week after I was promised. I'm not even sure if I'll see the money I had already earned but wasn't given. However, at the end of the day, it was fixed.

- The coaches do not communicate with each other.

- Terrible structure

- The point system itself.

- When you are hired you are supposed to learn everything in about a week or two, which makes sense but you will not be taught everything and will be written up when they forget to teach you something that you don't know yet and be called slow regardless.

- You are not paid for what you do and will be taken advantage of. There is a team called Cap 2 and the HBA team, in Cap 2 you are only supposed to zone the isles, do top stock, picks, and trucking, returns, and the occasional pallet. In HBA you are mainly to do price changes, clearance reviews, counts, outs, top stock, returns, the occasional pallet, and zoning. The overnighters are to mainly do the pallets. I constantly saw Cap 2 work in ALL of the areas of Walmart working off pallets and doing trucking alongside HBA and even doing what they call "freight swarms".

- You rarely get the equipment needed for your job to actually do your job and make it quicker unless you hide some of your own.

- They don't take into account physical conditions that you may have.

- A miserable energy. Regardless of who I talked to even coaches say how much they hate their job and just being there.

When my son was born he was admitted to the NICU. I had to take more time off than allowed with FMLA to take care of his medical needs and I was fired for taking too much time off to do so. Why didn’t I have PTO time? Because I was denied promotion to Full-Time after a one week stay in the hospital four months prior to my son’s birth. I had a brain hemorrhage (high blood pressure forced blood through the walls of a cavernoma adjacent to my brain stem). When I went to talk to HR and ask if I was still eligible to go full time, the assistant manager over my department said “Absolutely not. It’s a reward for employees who work 40 hours without attendance issues.” “I was in the hospital with a brain hemorrhage!” “Well, if you were in the hospital then you weren’t working 40 hours, were you?” This company doesn’t give any concern for the health and well-being of their employees or that of their families.

They hire so many teenagers or persons unable and unwilling to learn the English language there is always a language barrier. As a lead you will be blamed for your associates not preforming well. You can call out sick 5 times in a 6 month span. They do not accept Dr. notes or excuses so plan your sickness around your days off. They do not pay for Holidays you will be expected to work all of them. The bonuses that you can acquire depends on if your store is doing well, if it is doing well your bonus will be calculated by the amount of days you have called off in a 4 month period, if you have called off 3 or more times you will not receive a share of that bonus even if you have worked overtime, come in on your off days or basically almost killed yourself getting your area like they want it.

- NO VTO or voluntary time off. Their new "VTO policy" only lets you take up to 3-4 days off whether sick or to just take time off. After it's not even disciplinary, just right to termination. 
- HEAVY favouritism. People in the lower ranks can't have time off, while managers take OOT every 2 weeks. 
- Pay holiday pay by taking it out of your PTO hours. Meaning you are getting paid what you already had.
-Upper management such as team leaders and above don't help out.
- To apply to another department, you have to wait 6 months to a year. Even if you quit or are let go.

Even when you put in for a vacation expecting to leave soon and find out you have been scheduled more hours than you usually receive in same amount of time. Dr appointments are no different if you have an appointment and you must request it ahead of schedule don't count on it. 
There is no way to advance at Wal-Mart anymore, hours get cut and cut and cut again with out notice. 
It doesn't matter how hard you work or how much you give they do not care and will just take and take however much you are willing to give without so much as a pat on the back. But, hey, isn't that what your co-workers are for?? Begging you not to quit? Sam Walton would be dearly ashamed at what the company he loved and prided himself on has become. He was all about his employees!!! How times have changed.

There are several cons about working at Walmart. First, Walmart does not pay as well as many other major retailers such as Target and Costco, which both pay a minimum of $15 an hour. Second, Walmart takes away your previously earned raises when they bump the base pay up. This year I received my second pay raise, which bumped me from $13.16 to 13.42; however, my pay second pay raise was taken away when the Walmart raised its base pay from $12.90 an hour to $14. I now only make $14.16 an hour, instead of the $14.42 an hour that I should be making, which is unbelievable to me because currently my pay is only $0.16 more than any associate that is now hired in my department. It's unbelievable to me that I have been at Walmart for almost three years and I only make 16 cents more an hour than brand new associates. Third, most Walmart managers were previously Walmart associates and the vast majority do not have any prior training in management. This leads to many Walmart managers either trying to micromanage employees, not behaving professionally, or not knowing how to properly communicate with associates.

WalMart has an exceptional Health & Wellness division that offers a variety of pharmacist roles. You can move up in the company, but openings are limited.
benefits, understanding, flexible, kind, good atmosphere.
cons: The culture in some stores and divisions can be toxic, and it's a dice roll on which you're going to get. This can also change when store managers change, and it's effectively ignored by the home office. In fact, even divisions in the Home Office have some pretty brazen behaviors. There is little to no real focus on developing associates professionally in any way except to help Walmart, and even that is fleeting, despite the ads otherwise (like the $1 college tuition, which is to a non-accredited school and only for courses related to your job role). As you move up in the ranks, there are several levels of borderline abusive job roles, where you can expect nearly zero work-life balance. This seems to be true in all divisions.

You get bonuses once every year i think for having very little or no points (points are what you get if youre late or call in). We have this thing called ppto (protected paid time off) which are minutes/hours of work time that accumulates as you work. It basically lets you get paid to not work. For example, if you have 1 hour of ppto, you can spend it and leave work an hour early or come in an hour late and get paid for that hour and not be given a point. If you have 8 hours of ppto, you can spend all 8 hours and not come in at all for your shift and be paid for the entire day.

I am a closeted member of the LGBT community, when it comes to my job I prefer not to share that detail of my life with my coworkers because of past issues I’ve had in prior work environments. I went out on medical leave due to a chronic condition and came back to my entire department debating over my gender identity/sexual orientation. When the harassment of myself as well as multiple other people in our department/store as a whole was reported to upper management, we were told there wasn’t enough “proof” of what had been said to all of us DIRECTLY, to follow through with serious disciplinary action, therefore we were ignored and every day I get to attend work right next to my main harasser who is fully aware of who reported him now. Not to mention if you are physically fit and have a good work ethic you will be used and abused and dismissed the moment you have an issue with how you’re being treated. Employees having worked in said department for over 9 years haven’t been trained on things I was taught to do within my first week of training, or they straight up refuse to take on the tasks that are clearly part of our job description, and guess what, management happily turns a blind eye to this fact so long as the work is getting done by the two people who will actually do it.

He spoke to and directed a differentially abled worker on my team far too harshly and insensitively, to the point of making me incredibly uncomfortable. My immediate manager also seemed to be a "climber" and didn't seem to care much about his subordinates as much as he cared about his own success.

review: Not for the faint at heart
pros: consistent hours, great team and staff

-Not stressful on overnights, enjoy working alone 
-Plenty of opportunities to change positions or go to a different shift. 
-Ability to transfer to other stores. If you decide to move you can always have a job lined up since Walmart is everywhere. 
-Discount card perk is nice but it's excluded on some food and that's a con. Discount should apply on everything across the board. 
-Decent pay for my area WITH my shift differential, not anything to brag about! Overnights gets a 1.50 shift differential, I would not consider it decent pay if I was making only base pay of 13
-Plenty of opportunity to advance and receive promotions. Any of the management positions seem to pay really well. An assistant manager or a "team lead" as they call it apparently makes 65k a year.
-Hour lunches are pretty cool, I like that.

Management is often rude and hostile, and there's been multiple times where I have been asked/pressured/demanded to stay late, and since I get out at 10 at night, staying late means coming home around midnight. Favoritism in completely rampant in my store. Some of my coworkers blatantly take extra breaks and go to lunch together so their area is without coverage, and management turns a blind eye. If you are not one of the favorite employees, you will be talked down to, yelled at, and likely threatened with your job regularly. 
Keeping the store clean and keeping our meat and produce backroom organized is not a priority at all for management, until it becomes bad enough that we have to dedicate an entire day to fixing these issues instead of stocking and assisting customers. 
Having the equipment you need to do your job is a nonexistent concept at my store, and managers usually get annoyed if you bring that up to them. In general, it is difficult to approach management with any sort of issues, as even if they are around, they may brush you off, ignore you, or scream at you.

Honestly, the biggest issue for me was the customers that walked into my Walmart. I had worked in fast food and retail for years but working for Walmart the customers here are so different. The types of customers that rolled into the Walmart I worked at were terribly mean. I've heard them scream over basically nothing, I've seen them throw things I've been called every name in the book even while trying to stay nice and keep my cool but their tough to handle especially if you work night shift. As well as the lack of communication from management and the never ending call offs from your co workers you will always go home stressed and crying feeling over worked and partially dead.

1. We either didn't have the tools to do the jobs they asked me to or the tools were broken, yet the manager still yelled at us if something didn't get done (she knew the tools weren't there or were broken).
2. Minimal training = angry customers. You really do have to learn on the job because they don't train you much. You just have to figure things out as you go and when you're new that means customers get angry when you don't know certain things.
3. There are so many customers to help constantly and so many tasks that must get done. It was very very busy, at least when I worked there.

I was SCREAMED at by a supervisor for "wasting time" rotating inventory, and told to just "shove the (expletive) wherever it fits, don't worry about expiration dates". There were too few handheld scanners for all employees to actually get one. Also, this location has a habit of hiring too many new applicants, essentially creating a hostile work environment, where employees are in constant competition with their coworkers in hopes of keeping their job.

This job can be back breaking and sometimes a real pain. I don't always get equipment I need and I cannot successfully aid any customers when they ask for help. I have worked their long enough that they want me to work full time. However does not give me the desired flexibility to have my Friday and Saturday off to spend with family. It may say it is a family company but really they will work you really hard and sometimes in environments that make you sick and some days I have to struggled to get to such a far away location. The company also did not approve of my transfer request and corporates did little to help and just shut my case down immediately. All in all. Depending on the location it is a decent workspace. Otherwise be prepared for a shocking environment to work in. I have so many reasons as to why I want to leave the company.

40+ every week. No punishment for overtime, unless you milked it. Fair pay for the customer service industry. I've been in customer service for over a decade and Walmart: 1. Genuinely cares about us employees. 2. Training is GREAT. You dont go out on your own until you're ready and confident in your ability. And if you want to learn a different role they'll make time for you to train there too, no questions asked. 3. Culture. Walmart culture centers on love. Kindness. Just be a good human, they'll support you. 4. Humanity over profit. SUPER RARE IN ANY INDUSTRY. They put PEOPLE OVER PROFIT. EVERYTIME. I love my job. I've for sure worked waaayyyyyyy worse.

Working for Walmart has its good and bad like anything else in life or job. I was there for 17 Years i started as a front end cashier and ended up with my Certification Technician certificate.
I'm able to pay my bills

* Accessible. Will usually accept most types of people for as long as they meet the standard requirements for employment.
* Wage Growth. This may vary from store to store, region by region, but in just the past 5 years wages have grown from federal minimum to almost $15/hr in some regions.
* Diverse Team. This varies from store to store, but often times you will find yourself among wholesome and diverse coworkers who may not care much about the company, but will care a lot about you (management is hit or miss here).
* Benefits. If you're full-time, expect benefits after your probationary period (between 30 and 90 days). If you're part-time, you might as well go for open enrollment because it takes 12 months to get benefits.
* Transferrable. After 90 days, you may choose to change departments, store locations, or even shift into an entire different division (store, club, distribution, home office, etc).

Not a good place to work

* Policy over People. It will always hang over the heads of hourly associates. Some exceptions can be made, but if you're late too often it's an automatic termination even if management doesn't want to actually terminate the associate.
* Demanding Job "Positions". Crosstraining and flexible skillsets are common and associates will find themselves working jobs they're not hired to do.
* Abusive Customers. Most people view Walmart very poorly and will extend that perception onto associates in a manner where it's outright abuse. Once an associate takes off their vest and leaves the store the same customers can be delightful and kind.
* Flies. Yes, literal flies. This one may sound like a joke, but it's a truth that might not be exclusive to Walmart. I have personally worked in two different stores and flies in the break room is almost always excessive and out of control. The primary issue? Open top trash cans. It's been almost 10 years and it's still seems to be standard to just keep open top trash cans. The countermeasure is usually store-use fly paper off the shelf and one of those blue light ECOLABs (which honestly never seems to do that good of a job).

Right from the beginning, I realized I was in for it because they hired me no question, no interview, nothing. The upper management never got to know me and they still don't know who I am after 6 months. They are more than aware that morale is low, because they go around almost nightly repeating "we appreciate you" to me and the team. At the same time, they tell you constantly how replaceable you are. THEY DO NOT TRAIN. It took me 3-4 months to be able to go in and say to myself "I got this." Every night, I was thrown in with the sharks. They use online programs called ULearns to prime you for the job. They're terrible. Youre most likely to get some ex-military hard-ass "coach" manager who still thinks they're in Vietnam. I respect the military, but its no excuse to be a......whatever. They stress that you concern yourself with things that have nothing to do with you, like what time they left the shift previous and what high position manager plans to walk through the store. I go in ON TIME, they tell me what they need from me, I do it, I go home. That's it. THAT is my concern. They CONSTANTLY spit jargon they expect new people to already know (zoning, topstock, vizpicking, QPC, plugging, TC, on-hand, baling) and share news with the expectation that everyone is on the same page already. You could spend 4 nights in a row consistently in a section you know well and are still learning, and then on night 5 youre thrust into a brand new section with zero prior knowledge.

- Difficult communication with upper management within main store - Difficult implementation with devices/ programs used for inventory purposes - Communication is difficult with the program used to request L.O.A/F.M.L - Little forgiveness in regard to the unpredictability of chronic illnesses

It makes for a very, very stressful environment when I cannot get enough of my work done. The management just don't schedule people that they do have, so other departments always need help with customer service, so they grab associates from other places no matter how busy they are. This has caused just pure exhaustion in me and my associates. I can name so many who are ready to leave at the drop of a hat because it's becoming draining and miserable to go to work. I get paid 11.50 to help do everything in the store, half of which are positions that get paid so much more than I do. Also, with the shifts to teams, I went from working in 1 department to 6, but we never got new associates.

Overworked and underpaid. Not a positive culture. If you are not a brown noser or lazy you won’t get promoted. It’s not about what you know it’s who you know. You can a great worker, dependable and well rounded but won’t get any recognition but you can be the laziest worker but if you know the right people that’s all you need. I even had the people lead approach me in hostile manner stating
, “oh is your name …, oh okay because I heard you haven’t been taking lunches, so why is that?”. This is what the company promotes. She also approached another employee to say, “oh I heard you was taking about like what’s up you got a problem or what?”. To my surprise she has gotten another promotion where she will now be making over 70k a year. I have over 10 plus years retail experience, 2 years management experience, 5 plus years call center experience, an associates of science and a Bachelor of Arts but they wouldn’t pay me more than $11.90/hr.

We were barely staffed to handle a day's work beforehand, now we have to somehow keep the place afloat with multiple members in quarantine. Our market manager is also fantastic, but those higher than him, less so. While I was very pleased to gain the opportunity give vaccinations, it is unfortunate that those of us with this additional training and responsibility are not given any addition to our wages as compensation. I have recently found out that people in my position with less experience are being paid a fair bit more than we are at nearby Walmarts, which makes me feel undervalued. If it were not for my fabulous team, I would definitely be out of there. My manager has said the same thing about us, as she'd otherwise prefer a location that is much less stressful with a better commute. I have been searching on Indeed for a few weeks to see what other opportunities are available.

pros: Great pay, benefits and co-workers

Huge company means opportunity to move around. Pretty stable. Healthy culture depends on strong teams and good leadership. Lifers are few and far between in the Bay Area but it’s legend in Home Office. Not as bad as people think Walmart is, not as great as they think they are. If you find a good management team, hang on for dear life since that will set the tone for everything - work/life balance and team culture, push back and stakeholder management, negotiating for headcount. If you do well (meets or above) annual raise is basically guaranteed and the company is doing strong enough to consistently meet goals for bonus. “Unlimited” PTO for eComm teams.

Prime example of being a cog in the corporate machine. Been at the company over 5 years through multiple reorgs, the most recent one in fall 2020 was the most brutal - levels simply removed so people demoted or promoted seemingly at random, people placed in roles where it’s a poor fit, and recruiting/HR is a mess. Getting jerked around happens enough to you or people you know that eventually you just feel grateful to have a job or fed up enough to leave. Always under resourced so stress can be high. Internal promotions are standard 10% so you better negotiate in high on base salary while you can since RSUs and vacation (even before Unlimited policy) are standard per level too. It just means the longer you stay at the company, the less likely you may be making market rate.

- There are no raises. 
- Management tends to play favoritism when considering promotions/new job considerations rather than effort.
- Work ethic and effort doesn't matter. Some people show up and hardly do work making you do their portion of work so you don't fall behind, and they still get paid the same and you are treated the same by management.
- Most associates work with the bare minimum of effort and dedication, because there is no incentive to over achieving and going above the standard. 
- Inconsistent schedule starting out. Schedule was constantly changing within the first year at Walmart, making outside life unmanageable and tiring. Some days I'd be the "closer" working 2:00PM-11:00PM, then I'd be schedules as the "opener" working 8:00AM-5:00PM the following day, and various other shifts between. It was difficult to focus on school, family, and personal life with constantly changing shifts from week to week.

I'm not sure if this is just my store, but I have several cons.
The management treat you like disposable machines. The moment you're no longer useful to them or try to think for yourself, they will toss you out and replace you with some other person who will abide to their ever last waking whim. I've heard from several managers who I'm friends with who have straight told me they're instructed to treat associates poorly and not make connections with them. How do you make bonds and a healthy motivated team with people you are told not to connect with?
I mentioned benefits as a pro, but honestly if you're working for Walmart chances are you qualify for government assistance and any assistance you can get from the government will be miles better then anything Walmart has to offer. If you do want to give Walmarts benefits a try you have to jump through miles of hurdles and headaches to possibly find out you don't even qualify for their benefits. They say you qualify for benefits after a certain time, but I've been full time for a year and have worked for the company for 4 years all together and according to my HR rep I still don't qualify. Did I mention I'm diabetic? Well no mater Walmart doesn't care. If I cant afford medication they'll work me till I can't work anymore.
The discount you receive after 3 months isn't awful, but you don't even save on groceries for the most part the one thing you may really use a discount for the most. Can't feed your children oh well have 10% off this new TV.
The pay starts at $11 an hour which isn't bad or is it? Now that I think about it the Starbucks down the road pays their employees $15 an hour, Best buy makes $14, Target makes $15, McDonald's makes $13 depending on location. You know actually that $11 for all the freight, short staff, management treating you like trash, poor benefits and a discount that is actually a joke doesn't sound so appealing. Walmart should only be a placeholder if you for some reason simply can't get a job elsewhere or just need something until you can find something better.
You can get bad management witch will make you feel used and abused.

Walmart has good and bad managers. My suggestion when looking for a new position or an internal transfer, ask questions in the interview(s) to ensure the position is a good fit for you. Remember that interviews are not only for the company/hiring manager to determine if they want you on their team; Interviews are also to help you determine if you want to work for that company and manager.
Walmart does have a rich history of culture. It has seemed that they are losing the culture over the last few years, most likely due to all the acquisitions and management turnover. I think the biggest loss they are experiencing is a core principle Sam Walton had. He did NOT want to be the biggest retailer, he wanted to be the BEST retailer. He wanted to do this by:
- Selling quality merchandise at a great price.
- Taking care of the store Associates, so they would naturally take great care of the Walmart customers.

I don't know what to write about for the cons, so I'm just gonna tell you my experience. I got left alone on day 1 for the last 2 hours of my shift. My trainer clocked out because it was the end of her shift (not her fault). Her replacement just left and told me she would be around the corner, left from there too. I couldn't get help, I had to go wandering to find it. I had to ask a lady every time what to do, which wasn't her job, but she had the answers so she helped me. I asked for a transfer because I didn't want to work in that environment and I KNOW they have positions in almost every other department. I was told there weren't any positions I "would be happy with", I wanted anything else. They also told me there were no backend positions, my roommate works in cap-2 (back end, unloading trucks), he told me there were positions open in cap-2. She then went on to say that this was the job I was hired for because the position was open. I quit because I don't want to work for a company that doesn't care their employee is crying on her breaks and literally couldn't handle the stress of trying to learn a whole job by themselves. Walmart was already a pretty thankless place to work, but now it is even worse. The new management structure means no person is held responsible but the lowest ones on the totem pole (i.e. stockers). You will get blamed for things out of your control. If you attempt to fix any of the glaringly obvious problems you will be told you are the most insignificant person in the store and your only job is to open boxes to put on the shelf. 
The pay is decent for the area, but it honestly doesn't outweigh the stress of having to meet times for putting freight out. It also doesn't outweigh the strain put on your body from bending, lifting, and walking on hard concrete floors every night. 
Also, the stores get very hot at night during the summer/cold during the winter so be prepared to sweat profusely or freeze. 

Benefits are alright, but not the greatest. For a family of 3, look to pay approximately $200 per check for the cheapest insurance plan offered. The 10% discount you receive as an employee doesn't count towards most grocery items except during Christmas. You accrue sick and vacation days at a ridiculously slow rate. Which if you do use your sick days following the proper channels and policys, expect to be taken into the office and threatened with a disciplinary write up for failing to provide proper customer service since they are unable to do it for the actual reason. 
In fact, expect that to be the go to reason for any kind of write up if you haven't done anything wrong but management wants to retaliate because you called in or pointed out issues everyone wants to ignore within the store.
So much to do that it's overwhelming. Many people call out so you're always working so hard.

pros: They have medical benefits, dental benefits, stock options, a certain amount of money each year to go towards optical and the 401K the best thing about the 401K is they match you a dollar for dollar. The department I worked in was the food department I wasn't just a good worker I was a great worker. So because of that the store manager gave me free reign for my department. The best thing about that was dealing with all of the vendors. I learned a lot dealing with all the different vendors from Coca-Cola to Nabisco and everything in between. All the decisions started with me and stopped with me. I was able to learn a lot doing it that way. If s potato chips wanted to do a super bowl display the vendor would come to me tell me what he wanted to do how big of a display he wanted to make and then it was my decision on where to put it where it would get the most foot traffic and the most eyeballs seeing the display and to make sure the spot I decided to put it in would maximize their sales. With the store manager allowing me to do that I was able to learn so much. I had to talk with all the vendors I learned how to wheel and deal with them. It also taught me how important displaying a product in the correct place really is for that products sales. One other thing they do about 95% of their promoting within the company. When I worked there I just happened to get very lucky and had a fantastic store manager.

Favoritism is a huge problem with this company. If you are not apart of the “in crowd” you will not move up, regardless of how well you preform. Management is unethical, they pretend or try to make it look like they follow proper protocol. When I’m reality they do not. They will notify associates that they want to hire that they have the job, while they are still interviewing other candidates. I’ve seen them go as far as pushing the hiring process out to wait for a corrective action to fall off, for an associate they wanted to promote.

Constant changes to policies, Associates that don’t pull their own weight, and some managers are on a power trip, big wigs come in and start a line of stress down the chain of command! It doesn’t matter how good you are at your job, if wal-mart home office considers your job unnecessary you will be demoted or let go. Lack of staffing that pulls their weight, mostly, because home office keeps demoting and firing the good people. There is no set schedule, so you can’t plan your life around work! You struggle to find a sleep pattern, because of the swapping back and forth between all the different work hours! In the end, though it’s a job, and it was never meant to be convenient for you, and most of the cons I listed is because wal-mart is a corporation, but if wal-mart wasn’t a corporation pay wouldn’t be that great. I don’t think a JOB could get much better than wal-mart.

*Management as always, but it isn’t necessarily their fault we’re short staffed in my department. This job is very physically demanding, you are moving around the whole store for all eight hours of your shift. A lot of people can’t handle it.
*Only get one weekend day off. That’s to be expected with this job however, weekends are the busiest days and you’re needed the most.
*At the time of this review I’m still in my first week, my feet & legs are SO SORE. However, I’m going from doing nothing but sitting at home for 3 months (thanks COVID), to working 40 hours a week constantly running around.
*I don’t like that they let everyone know “it’s easy to get promoted”. It isn’t easy, you have to work hard and show up, but more importantly they do play a lot of favorites there. If you’re close with the managers and do well, you will get promoted. But you have to know the right people.
*Some managers I don’t listen to you. And I get it, they’re very busy and constantly working, doing jobs that associates like myself can’t do. But I wish, if they weren’t going to do what they say they will, they would at least maybe have you write down your information so they can look at it later.

Salary management quickly forgets what it's like to be an associate. Example: I work very hard and most of the time it's only me and a few salary managers in total. Some days I need an extra 10 min on lunch to recharge and destress. They have no issues threatening a write up over 10 min over on lunch, but will turn a blind eye to associates that do nothing but walk around and talk all day! When covid hit last year walmart corporate removed attendance points for absences if you felt you needed to stay home, you could, but at the store level they were coaching associates for production, because they were calling in due to covid! I refused to write up any of my associates for this, but there were plenty that got coached and some that got terminated.

We used to have CSM’s (Customer Service Managers?) and there would be around 2-3 at all times. However, they demoted them and we have team leaders, and there’s only one at a time. They run the entire store essentially and are hard to find. Also, it is very easy to get fired, the points system is a joke. Customers are extremely rude and management does nothing to help you. In the event you react, you get in trouble. They change schedules after they’re made and if you don’t show up, you get a point. I remember I was told i was going to slow to complete a palette then later then later suffered from it by having to work 7 days straight with only 1 off day. I eventually got tired of it and just quit. I dont recommend this job to anyone. The pay sucks too and its only $12.80.

- Friendly and very helpful staff. Most customers were friendly as well.

- Could have a different food bar after x number of days of no injuries. Food we got then was pretty good too.

- Ability to work plenty of hours.

- I feel like $11 per hour was decent for a starter job. Working here 3+ years definitely helped me get through college.

- Flexible schedules. I was able to work mostly 9 AM - 6 PM schedules, which made each week's schedule easier to memorize.

- Could request time off, which was almost always approved. Never missed the Summer air show or the chance to visit my aging grandparents during my time here.

- Decent amount of work to do. Varies by dept, but mine (toys) was generally busy.

- Occasionally helping out other departments also helped diversify the work I did.

- Long one hour lunch break.

- We had a Nintendo Switch in our break room. Didn't use it much, but it was a fun alternative to browsing my phone during breaks.

Repetitive work, scanning backroom for items that needed to go out to the floor, and running carts, sometimes you’d get set in different departments but it’d only take a few shifts to learn and was overall pretty nice work, but the cons outweighed the ease/steadiness of the job. Hours worked was pretty consistent (40-hour work weeks) but the days you were scheduled for were not (shifting schedules around happened a lot, and they often didn’t care about how many days it’d leave you working in a row...). If you were fulltime, you were eligible for health insurance coverage. Regardless if you were fulltime or parttime, you got a discount card for 10% that you can use in the store, and the pay ($11) was decent when you’re not overworked and working pretty much more than one persons job.

Management/supervisors could care less about your health and schedule. Attempts to inform them that you couldn’t work a certain amount of days in a row without getting sick went through one ear and out the other. They could rework the schedules to make it so you’re working 6-7 days in a row without reprieve, have two days off, then rework it again to the same thing, which is physically and mentally draining. They also didn’t care to hire new people often enough to replenish the people that left or get fired - so you’d often work an area by yourself with an area that’s too big to work by yourself and be finished by the end of the day, and you’d basically be working two or three peoples jobs. As fun/repetitive as the work was, it wasn’t worth it when the management didn’t care about your health, physical AND mental.

Why work for a company who doesn't care about you? 

If you are thinking of a future at Walmart consider a few things. 

Look at the salaried members of management. Are they ever happy? How stressed are they? How do they treat/speak to their employees? 

Do you want to deal with them as your colleagues or worse, become like them? 

If the answer is no, then ask yourself this.. 

Why are you still there?

The final store I worked for has a store manager whom doesn't practice the tenants of the company has openly hazed associates doesn't create a inclusive environment refuses to leave the office spends a majority of his time on ESPN does not follow the teach train and grow standards for the company and has expectations that people who aren't trained will fully be able to exicute new programs before they roll out.

Hiring managers are not the managers you'll work under, so terms of employment will be completely ignored (Why I quit)
Changes in the workplace are announced publicly before privately, and typically contain outright lies for PR reasons.
Manipulative management will attempt to have you believe you're underperforming while stocking well above targets.
Recently Walmart cut schedule distribution and department heads in half, doubling workload across the board with no pay rise.
Covid requirements not followed, management even discriminated against me for wearing a mask too often. I was also promised no customer interaction then scheduled on the floor during business hours.
Orientation is done by HR (People Lead) who are not familiar with the roles they train for. Nothing shown in orientation was actually relevant to my job, and I had to be shown around again once I was scheduled.
HR (People Leads) are incompetent and refuse to make changes requiring HR, even with the approval of my team lead, head coach, and at one point, the assistant store manager, which essentially meant I had to talk to 4-5 people to make even minor changes to my job and availability, each of which had different, ridiculous requirements.
Getting hired requires nepotism. I applied 3 times with roughly the same qualifications, but only got hired when an employee I knew recommended me to 3 different managers. I don't believe it's possible to be hired alone at Walmart using a typical, healthy method in your job search

I would definitely recommend working at the Walmart Home Office in Bentonville as a young professional for a few years.

Pros:
- Very affordable cost of living
- Attractive corporate benefits (Walmart store discount, stock options, WLFC, 401k match, etc.)
- Strong company culture and values (instilled by Sam Walton)
- Strong corporate leadership
- Fayetteville (University of Arkansas, Dickson Street)
Flexibility Good Environment Nice Culture in office overall Friendly workplace

- Great work place

Office, Ownership over work, Startup feel
Great benefits, meet new people
cons: Tasks are very overwhelming at times and departments are often understaffed.

Point system was designed for the employee to fail. You only get 5 absences (including sick time, family emergencies, doctors appointment, childcare ect) and even if you couldn’t help the situation , you would get a point.

Make sure to have exposure of your work to senior leadership. It is important for them to see the value of your work. Unfortunately, Walmart has constant reorganizations and without senior leadership support and advocacy, chances are you will not survive

I ultimately decided to leave Walmart due to the home office location in Bentonville Arkansas. As a young professional, I had a great time for my first 1-2 years in Arkansas, but without family in the area or any connection to Arkansas I was ready to broaden my horizons and explore new opportunities in a larger city with more young professionals. If I already had a family and was looking for an affordable place to settle down, I could see myself living in Bentonville.

Cons:
- Bentonville (Small town with small young professional network)

Walmart has a point system. Five points and you're out. You get one point if you have to miss a shift. Doesn't matter if you're sick or your kid is sick. You get half a point if you are more than nine minutes late. Doesn't matter if there's traffic or your kid is sick. If you miss three or more days of work for being sick or something, you get no points. How does that make sense? Points go away 6 months after you get that point.
Also specific to my store, and probably some others, my management has never actually worked as associates in this department. They run it very badly because of that. Also, they definitely play favorites. We have one guy in our department that doesn't do any work and actually hinders the department and is extremely rude to everyone he doesn't like which is 80% of the department, but he is best friends with one of the managers. If we even say something against this guy, they will find a way to fire us. In fact, they have fired almost all of the competent members of our staff in the past couple of months for saying things that the managers did not like. I brought it up to the manager above them and they just tried to make me move departments. And they will lie to cover up why the people were fired.
Lastly, I have a diagnosed anxiety disorder with panic attacks, but I am on medications. The other day, I had a panic attack during work about both work and other issues. The next day, my managers confronted me, and basically told me that I can't be worrying about other things during work and I should just not have panic attacks during work because they're not paying me to do that.

Almost every aspect of the job is a con. Incompetent management that couldn't lead their way out of a paper bag, and don't make any effort to do much besides complain and hang out in the office all day. Can't motivate their employees to work properly, so they attempt to use fear to do so, instead of treating them like humans with emotions and feelings. Expect non management hourly employees to take on management roles without promotion so they can have someone else to blame for their own ineptitude. Create safety hazards to both customers and employees, but fail to address those that effect employees. Workload is ridiculous, and expectations totally unrealistic. They work good employees to the point of exhaustion, and don't train new ones so that the workload can be more evenly distributed. Pay long time employees the same as new hires, because everyone gets the same raise anytime one is actually given instead of basing it on quality of work. Home office is totally detached from how a regular store operates, and creates new systems, changes their minds, and then reverts back to essentially an old system. It's exactly what you would expect from a corporate giant such as Walmart, a total lack of empathy from the top down, and focused on ever increasing their already obscene profits at the expense of those who can't cope and burn out. This company makes you feel like you would rather die than come in for another day of emotional and physical abuse. This is that place, where hopes and dreams come to die. Look elsewhere if you want a job that's at the very least tolerable.

Okay. I am a reasonable person. I do not hate this job. There are a few things that I think work.

1) Teamwork. Walmart just went through a restructuring. Department managers are a thing of the past. Instead, you have team leads like myself. I oversee 5 departments. The good thing about this is that it helps to break down the walls that divided the departments before. You no longer have department managers that are territorial over their own areas and people. There are only associates within each department. Associates are much more willing to bring variety to their days by assisting in a new way.
2) Technology makes the job super easy. I never really need training on anything. Every device I pick up is as easy as a self-checkout. Nothing I've ever done was "hard."
3) Room for advancement. Walmart will take you as far as you are willing to go. Even now, I am being asked about the next level up. You just have to want it. 
4) The people. The people of Walmart have their own stereotype...but I like them. The customer service interactions are a refreshing break for me at times. I get along with my coworkers as well. I feel like we are soldiers in a war at times...and that brings out a sense of brotherhood.
5) Fast days. You work hard and go home tired.
The three day work week

cons: Managers do not care about you; your department will mostly likely be understaffed most of the time; my managers did not care if I was in school.
