Unreliable co-workers causing other to do more work.

1) No victories. The volume of a Walmart Supercenter creates a neverending wave of stock. We have what's known as the dreaded "2-truck night." It's when the warehouse is backed up and sends an extra trailer to your store. These were supposed to end at Christmas, yet here I am on January 29th telling you we had three 2-truck nights this week. It's like trying to mop up the ocean. 
2) Callouts. So, remember what I said about associates being willing to add variety to their days? The best way they have discovered to do this is to stay at home. Imagine, if you will, being the team lead overseeing 3 service areas (paint mixer, fabric cutter, and gun sales) in addition to your other departments. Now, imagine a Saturday that you are working and your ENTIRE TEAM calls in from every department you oversee. You better learn to clone yourself.
3) Morale. The reason they are calling out is because everyone hates their jobs. It is exhausting, thankless work. If you are an upbeat, positive person, you will soon learn how to keep that to yourself.
4) Customer complaints. Go ahead, admit it....you have said that Walmart is greedy because they won't hire any cashiers. You may have angrily told that to a Walmart stockboy while you were 15th in line at checkout. Now go back and read my cons. There were 6 cashiers scheduled...none of them showed up. You told off that stockboy because his coworkers laid out.
5) Micromanagement. There are multiple coaches (formerly assistant managers) in a Walmart Supercenter. If you are a hard worker that comes to work, every single one of them needs you. You are asked to do things that have nothing to do with your area by people you do not directly report to. You have to learn to say "no" to your superiors...which is a weird thing.

Training is very thorough and prepares you for all of the basics with step by step instructions such as proper scanning, bagging, etc.. You fill out hours of availability as part of the paperwork so they know when you're comfortable working and you are also allowed to change it in the future if the need arises. The work is flexible and management does not complain if you cut corners and just bag everything by shapes to speed up your line. Also, I live only about 10 minutes from my work site and pretty often see people I know shopping that can "visit" while I'm working which makes the experience a little more special than my last job which was privately held.

Experience
Working with a variety of people in age and personality
cons: The management not always helpful.

There is no work- life balance, you work 14-17hrs a day depending on which schedule you pick. The area manager gets handed all of the assignments/projects from upper management, and on top of that you have to deal with your area manager responsibilities, while making sure you reach your goal for the day. 
When you want a vacation they will ask why? 
Do not ever accept the first offer, because you will regret it after working long hours and working on your off days when the season hits. 
Area managers have to calculate every move, get comfortable with associates always being right even when they are at fault. 
Pray that you get a "good" operational manager, or even a coworker who will train you on the job. You will be thrown in the ocean with sharks (associates) who will want to see you fail, especially when you are new to the company.
If you want to work to the top, you have to carry on more projects and there is no team at that point. Its all about making yourself good.

Get treated like crap, get forced to do about fifteen departments jobs, then yelled at for not doing your actual job - or getting sent as a cashier out to push carts only to hear management yelling about lines - well gee if 3 of your cashiers weren't having to push carts cause you didn't schedule any freaking cart pushers maybe the lines - which were probably a couple lines with 2 or 3 people in them - our upper management would FREAK out about "lines" and it'd literally be one register had three people counting the one being checked out - that isn't a line. CONSTANTLY was spending 1/2 or more of my days at least half the week or more at times, sometimes ENTIRE shifts multiple days in a row forced to push carts because they were too cheap to hire more and too lazy/scared to fire the ones who weren't doing their freaking jobs or who just no called/no showed and didn't get fired for it/afraid if they did the horrible employees would come after them claiming discrimination even though they should easily have poor attendance or video footage of them wasting hours of time on the clock etc as evidence to dispute any such claims, etc. Not to mention the god-awful customers - screw the customers - some aren't bad, heck some are amazing, but at least a quarter to half on a given day were the rudest people ever and god help you when a Karen comes through or coupon-ers with their book trying to scam the store and trick new cashiers or just people that weren't gonna be happy and will lie right in front of your to CSMs or managers about you, etc. I could go on for literally days - but as said in pros - the ONLY good things about the job was the income and affordable insurance - and the income is still TERRIBLE - working 30-35 hours a week as a part timer for 4 years I was ONLY making $11.22 - maybe making $1100-1200 a month before taxes - with a roommate and an apartment that's under $600 a month TOTAL some months I was lucky if I had $30 bucks to spare - (should have been $11.66 by my count but every time they raised the base pay any annual raises you'd earn disappeared - granted you still made more than before but the whole thing about the annual raises was that it was a TINY little something for suffering another year in that crapshow - just cause the company chooses to increase pay shouldn't take that away imo - granted that wouldn't have drastically changed anything paycheck wise but still :P. Also, did I mention that if I didn't miss ONE day of work for the ENTIRE year - wasn't sick, didn't have to call out, leave early, have anything BESIDES a death in the immediate family - since you know - Walmart doesn't count aunts, uncles, nephews, nieces, cousins, etc as immediate family, even though grandparents - same degree of separation a parents sibling versus a parents' parent - since at least you get three days of bereavement - would net me a WHOPPING six MAYBE depending on hours and all - days of PTO that I could use TOTAL. I was there over four years and didn't EVER ONCE ask for any days off because I literally couldn't afford it. Then there's the whole favoritism, racism, sexism, and blatant letting some get away with murder just about while writing others up for the TINIEST of infractions or complaints, etc that my store had.

Managers look the other way with everything. It's really hard to get fired for anything other than attendance, and even with that, you get chance after chance, especially if the managers "like" you. If you show up you can pretty much guarantee you'll be able to keep your job, unless they eliminate your job altogether. The whole chain of command is extremely corrupt and it makes it easy to get away with things like taking two-hour lunches, calling in and using personal time to do whatever you want or to come in super late, etc. Store managers tend to not notice you beyond your first month or so where they pump you up for the possibility of having a "career." This can be a pro or a con however you want to look at it. Just be aware that the only way you're actually going to move up the ladder is if you pucker up that kisser and use it every chance you get. The best way to kiss arse is to pretty much never take a day off. Or sleep with an asst manager or whatever they're called nowadays. I've seen that one work too. You get an hour lunch which is nice and two paid 15 min breaks. There are times where it's fun to work at Walmart, like when you go to the Academy for a week and they give you a gas card that you can use for whatever. Every once in a while, a cool manager comes along but quickly disappears, but while they're there you may learn different things about different departments. I found out that being properly cross-trained isn't encouraged, but when a string of people call off you'll always be asked to do their job, regardless of whether you've been trained to do that job or not, and leave your area unattended to go to s-it. The baseline philosophies of Walmart are actually something that I believed in: "One Best Way." But what it boils down to is the store managers run their stores however they choose, and I guarantee their preferences have poor Mr. Sam rolling in his grave. If you're hellbent on feeling superior, have an affinity for power trips, and aim to learn as little as possible about how the store is run, a store manager at Walmart is perfect for you. I must say you'll meet some of the sweetest ladies in the world at Walmart. They can make or break your shift, and uplift your spirit, and teach you a lot about life and help you realize there's a world outside of Walmart and it's not that serious.
Decent benefits, insurance could be better. Occasional bonuses.

The pay sucks. For example, Target starting pay is $4.00 more per hour. They eliminate positions and therefore get rid of people all the time. If you've had a coaching on your record and they just so happen to re-structure the system, 
 kiss your job goodbye. Turnover is laughably high from the bottom to the top. Because they don't ever discipline employees and give them a million chances to f-up, you can expect to habitually be overworked along with being underpaid. You'll be doing three people's jobs regularly. And if you don't know how to do their job, you'll get a thorough 5-minute training session, most likely from a manager who knows even less than you do and be thrown to the wolves. They seem to pride themselves on having up-to-date, technologically advanced equipment. But most of the time the crappy thing doesn't work, or has a dead battery, and then there's only one working and your supervisor has to steal it because they actually need it. Then they don't give it back, or leave it on a cart somewhere for another person to steal. As well, our cash recycler was a piece of utter garbage, despite being regularly cleaned and updated. It's the most frustrating thing for the employees and the customers, but has no overall effect on management, so they don't care. Another thing, Walmart is cheap and that equates to long lines, no cashiers, self-checkout only scenarios. They cut hours all the time and force people to go home if they're going to even get 20 minutes of overtime. Or they'll cut hours altogether and you'll end up with a roster of 5 people for the entire day to spread out across the entire front end. Sometimes cashiers would have to take my keys and cover my lunch because they don't schedule another manager with me like they're supposed to. I remember one day, when I was about 7 months pregnant, I stood on my feet for my entire shift- 10 hours- at the customer service desk. No breaks, no lunch. Nothing. The lines stretched to the back of the stores, and one of my morning cashiers closed her line and walked off (I am not being hyperbolic). I told her "just go" and continued to hack away at my customer service line. The petty, backstabbing politics are potent among the managers. Don't ever expect them to take your side in a disagreement or see anything from your perspective. If you receive a coaching, beware of open-dooring it. Especially if you go above the store manager's head because you're uncomfortable speaking to him. You'll have a target on your back for the rest of your time at Walmart. If you ever plan to transfer, do not make your store manager or direct supervisor aware until you've successfully mapped out a plan with the other store and spoken to that store's management. If they know you wish to transfer, they'll smile at you and wish you good luck. Then swiftly give you a "bad grade" on your evaluation, not tell you about it, and feed you some bulls-it line about how you need to work just a little harder, but you're doing okay, and please sign here. Always ask what your performance is rated at your evaluations. If you have a needs improvement rating, you can't transfer or move up. It's dangerous to work at Walmart. You'll be required to watch a video on how to get out alive if there's an active shooter. There's a reason you have to watch this training video several times a year. While I worked there, the El Paso shooting happened. There's no security at Walmarts and there were numerous bomb threats and "scares" following the tragedy in El Paso. They put a police officer at the door for about two weeks, and when everything died down they stopped paying for that, even though it greatly deterred shoplifters and general mischief. Lastly, they don't take sexual harassment seriously. I had a close friend transfer to another Walmart only to be regularly harassed by the store manager. When she reported it, corporate never so much as followed up with her. However, they did make the store manager aware, creating a volatile environment for her that resulted in her quitting. That disgusts me, and I can never respect a company that treats victims of sexual harassment (male and female) like they don't matter, and it's easier to not disrupt the daily goings-on. But, someone at corporate will take the time to be petty and give the store manager a head's up that one of his employees is accusing him of sexual harassment. Truly the trashiest, sleaziest, laziest, shadiest people I've ever associated with worked with me at Walmart. And those people were the ones who succeeded, despite numerous complaints to corporate and various confrontations with employees and even their girlfriends. I wouldn't wish a career at Walmart on my worst enemy. Ironically, one of my worst enemies, while I worked there, was the HR manager. I thank God every day they told me I couldn't come back. It was a shock and a bummer at first but what a blessing in disguise! I learned so much about myself but it was a painful, emotionally trying few years that I try so hard to look fondly upon. TL;DR: Just apply at Target.

review: Just doing this to use the app.
Definitely Not A Long Term Job
pros: Amazing Time to work at the store
They pay you for every cent worked.

- High pay for the area if you have no experience in anything, I literally mean nothing.
- Very fast hiring process
- Lots of overtime if you want extra pay
- Lots of choices for your schedule, weekends (3 /12 hr days) or weekdays (4/10 hr days - or 5/8 hr days) or a mix for swing shifts, this is for Full-time. Part-time would be 2 /12 hr days for weekend shift or 2.5 /10hr days for week day shift, however I dont think you can come in for overtime or get benefits if your part-time.
- You build up PTO fairly quickly after your 90 day probation period and you can use that whenever you like, regardless if your managers dont want you to, its one thing that is very worker orientated over there. When you have earned your time-off you can take it whenever you like, and thats that.
- Once you have been there a while you can switch to different positions within the DC and that can help build work-experience in other fields other than stacking boxes.

You life will be made a living hell if your manager doesn't personally like you.

- Very strict on everything, down to the smallest detail, your not micro-managed by a person but by a automatic machine. It tracks everysingle thing you do; the tasks of your job, to using the bathroom. As in, there will be a gap in your time record and that needs to be made up or accounted for, its not uncommon to have your supervisors ask you where you where for that last 10 mins because you used the restroom. It uses time to account for every employees tasks and how efficient they are.
- There is an atomshphere of "every employee is supposed to go above and beyond and do more work than nessesary". If you do that you are treated fairly, however if you just show up for a paycheck and do your work and leave you are treated inferior, like you are not a good employee because you dont want to do extra work to make the supervisors look good. I saw a lot of this.
- Very short breaks
- A few tyrannical supervisors who get-off to dominating subordinates, the typical psychopaths
- Get fired for anything, however they dont "fire" you they just make your life miserable until you quite so you are not eligible for unemployment. Saw that a TON. The reason is because the most common job at the DC is terrible, pays well but is so brutal on your body that the turn-over rate is above 50%, its a churn-and-burn business. Take young people in, chew them up, spit them out if they cant handle it. It is what it is.

Depending on the upper management; work can be a little taxing to tedious when it comes to perfection, and some mangers resort to verbal and emotional abusing some of their employees. ( though not many and not often) The company does have a strict ethics program to handle this but it would seem that some level of biases has slightly corrupted this over time, and as a result it can be ineffective at times. But by far the worst con that comes to my mind is sadly, the mind set of some of the people who do simply come into shop, but to verbally and emotionally abuse any employee in anyway that they can, leading up to and including threats of termination. Coworkers tend to get along but that doesn't stop them from being piety and bitter towards one another and some even go out out of their way to threaten one another employment and even go to extremes to intimidate one another if they feel that they are being challenged in anyway. If any employee feels underemployed, helpless and targeted, it is easy for them for quickly to lash out at others or take drastic actions, causing the company to enforce a very strict " no rehire" policy making it an overall unforgiving and uncaring place to work.
